head.title: She Brings a Succulent Taste Of Jamaica to the Courthouse

hedline.hl1: She Brings a Succulent Taste Of Jamaica to the Courthouse

abstract.p: Article on Fauzia Abdur-Rahman, whose food cart outside Bronx Criminal Courthouse serves mix of Jamaican specialties, Indian flat breads and Italian dishes; photo (M)

block.p: Eric Warner, the lead prosecutor at the trial of Amadou Diallo, will be leaving the Bronx district attorney's office next month to become a partner at a Midtown Manhattan law firm. Last week, a friend sardonically asked him if he was going to miss Bronx cuisine.
''I told him, I know you're saying that as a joke,'' Mr. Warner said, ''but the truth is, I'm going to miss Fauzia, the cart lady.''

Eric Warner, the lead prosecutor at the trial of Amadou Diallo, will be leaving the Bronx district attorney's office next month to become a partner at a Midtown Manhattan law firm. Last week, a friend sardonically asked him if he was going to miss Bronx cuisine.
''I told him, I know you're saying that as a joke,'' Mr. Warner said, ''but the truth is, I'm going to miss Fauzia, the cart lady.''
Few people who live and work near the Bronx courthouses know Fauzia Abdur-Rahman's full name. Some call her Fauzia. Others just call her Ma.

But ever since 1996, when she set up a cart on the corner of 161st Street and Sheridan Avenue, across the street from the criminal courthouse, and began serving a mix of Jamaican specialties, Indian flat breads and Italian dishes under the sign Heavenly Delights, Ms. Abdur-Rahman has contributed far more to life on the corner than just what she dishes out in containers.

Neighborhood children stop by to show her their report cards. Local residents stop by for advice. Ms. Abdur-Rahman, who calls everyone sweetie, has made so many friends here that whenever she considers moving her cart to Manhattan, where she would probably make more money, she decides against it.

''After a time, I had such a good bond with the people here -- some got married or moved or changed careers, and I went through all those changes with them -- so they were like friends,'' she said. ''I couldn't leave.''

When Ms. Abdur-Rahman was growing up on the island of Jamaica, her family was so well off that she never had to lift a finger around the house. But when an her aunt offered her a free trip to New York after college, she left and never returned.
For a time, she worked for the city's Department of Social Services. But after she had the first of her three children, she could not make ends meet.

Her mother, Ruby Richards, who now lives with her in Harlem, suggested that she go into business and taught her two specialties: sorrel, an herbal drink brewed with ginger, and codfish cakes, a deep-fried Jamaican specialty. From there, Ms. Abdur-Rahman branched out on her own. Now she is known for her lemon cakes, banana pudding and jerk chicken.
Her lunch specials sell for $4 and $6 apiece, and she is sold out by 2 p.m. One recent afternoon at 2:30, a woman in a hot pink shirt peered longingly into the metal trays.
Ms. Abdur-Rahman lifted the lid. ''It's the bottom of the pan,'' she said.
''That's O.K.,'' the customer replied. ''That's usually the sweetest part.''
